elements.content: 3738The photocatalytic reaction mechanism of RhB in the presence of a uranyl complex.24,39103396352514650912344311481111424011126151801341112526652178511214947121415185253079224715773669011521334113857313575041107638181383443912613† Electronic supplementary information (ESI) available: The selected bond lengths and angles for complexes 1–4 are listed in Tables S1–S4. Their hydrogen bonds are shown in Table S5. Infrared spectra and TG curves of complexes 1–4 are shown in Fig. S1–S4 and Fig. S5–S8. Fig. S9–S12 and Fig. S13–S16 present the PXRD patterns and UV-vis spectra of the complexes 1–4, respectively. Fig. S17–S19 present the degradation efficiency of complex 2. The degradation efficiency of complexes 3 and 4 are shown in Fig. S20–S22 and Fig. S23–S25, respectively. Copies of this information may be obtained free of charge, by quoting the publication citation and deposition numbers CCDC 1008960 for (3), 1008961 for (1), 1008962 for (4) and 1008963 for (2). For ESI and crystallographic data in CIF or other electronic format see DOI: 10.1039/c4ce01473a

† Electronic supplementary information (ESI) available: The selected bond lengths and angles for complexes 1-4 are listed in Tables S1-S4. Their hydrogen bonds are shown in Table S5. Infrared spectra and TG curves of complexes 1-4 are shown in Fig. S1-S4 and Fig. S5-S8. Fig. S9-S12 and Fig. S13-S16 present the PXRD patterns and UV-vis spectra of the complexes 1-4, respectively. Fig. S17-S19 present the degradation efficiency of complex 2. The degradation efficiency of complexes 3 and 4 are shown in Fig. S20-S22 and Fig. S23-S25, respectively. metadata.title: UO 2 2+ -amino hybrid materials: structural variation and photocatalysis properties
